inst.txt:
Big History is the study of history
  • from the beginning of the universe
  • to the present moment.
Because most of history was caused by nature, such as the formation of the Earth, studying science occurs while studying big history.

Big history initially examines
  • large scale eras,
  • trends, and
  • cause-and effect relationships,
leaving details to ordinary history and science courses.
Is big history only concerned with human history?
inst.exp: Big history studies the time before humans existed as well as human history to the present day.

inst.txt: Is science is essential to the study of big history?
inst.exp: Science is essential to understanding topics such as how the Sun formed and how humans evolved.

inst.txt: Is the alliance of Hittite king Telepinu with the Kizzuwatnas against the Mitannis a good topic for studying early in a big history course?
inst.exp: This topic is too small and specific to include in big history, let alone early in the course.

  • Ma: One million years ago (mega years ago), and
  • Ga: One billion years ago.

inst.txt:
The previous question describes events from the largest eras of history. They are:
  1. The cosmological era, starting with the the Big Bang 13.8 Ga;
  2. The solar era starts with the formation of the Solar System 4.6 Ga;
  3. The animal era started about 600 Ma.
  4. Finally, the human era started about 120 ka.

inst.txt: Recall in the last unit we divided all of history into four eras:

This lesson is about the cosmological era. The cosmological era, lasting from the beginning of the Universe 13.7 Ga to the formation of the solar system 4.6 Ga, is also divided into four eras:
  • the promordial era, beginning with the Big Bang, when the Universe contained only radiation and atomic nuclei;
  • the atomic era, when the Universe cooled enough for atoms to form, 380 ka;
  • the stellar era, when stars began to form 200 Ma after the Big Bang; and
  • the galactic era, when galaxies formed, 1 Ga after the Big Bang.
